column3: Title
column4: Authors
column10: COMMENTS (either add comments here or using the comment function in a given cell. Do not write in the cell itself!)
column14: Number of coauthors from non-academic institutions
column15: Number of coauthors from governmental organizations (USGS, etc)
column16: Forecast spatial scale (point, multipoint, regional, national, global)
column17: If spatial scale is "point" or "multipoint": geographic coordinates from google maps (see notes)
column18: Forecast ecosystem: forest, grassland, freshwater, marine, desert, tundra, atmosphere, agricultural, urban, global, other
column19: Forecast class: biogeochemical or organismal (population or community)
column20: How many forecast variables are discussed in the paper
column25: If specified: more detailed description of model (e.g., Bayesian hierarchical, machine learning, named model (e.g., PROTECH), etc)
column26: Model covariate class(es) used in this study: meteorological, physical, chemical, or biological
column27: Does the paper explicitly identify that random effects were included? (y/n)
column28: Does the paper explicitly talk about latent variables, using this terminology? (y/n)
column33: Are multiple modeling approaches compared (NOT including null models)? (y/n)
column37: What type of null model (e.g. climatology, persistence)
column39: Time step of forecast output (in days)
column40: How often are new forecasts produced (in days)
column42: Model training period mentioned in paper? (y/n)
column44: Iterative forecast (i.e., data updating forecasts iteratively)? (y/n)
column45: What technique of data assimilation? (e.g., KF, enKF, refit, update IC, etc)
column46: Latency of observation data for assimilation (response variable). If not provided, mark "unspecified." Convert units to days
column48: If uncertainty is propagated: Is uncertainty propagation analytic or ensemble-based?
column49: What sources of uncertainty were incorporated?
column57: If at least two categories of uncertainty were partitioned, what was the dominant source of uncertainty?
column58: If the dominant source varies by forecast horizon, season, etc. please describe here
column61: Paper states that forecast was evaluated (y/n)
column62: Forecast evaluation results reported in paper (y/n)
column63: List all skill metrics used (e.g. R2, RMSE, bias, MAE)
column64: Is forecast performance assessed at multiple forecast horizons (results must be reported in paper/supplimental info)? (y/n)
column65: How many forecasting cycles are evaluated/assessed, with the results reported in the paper? (PLEASE READ NOTES HERE)
column66: How many total forecasting cycles are included for that variable in this paper (both those that are evaluated and those that are not)
column67: Maximum forecast horizon such that the forecast is better than the null model (out of any models used). Provide answer in days
column69: Maximum driver latency (latency of the driver with the longest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column70: Minimum driver latency (latency of the driver with the shortest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column71: Temporal coverage of data used to create this forecasting paper (in days; your best guess is fine here)
column72: Is new data (driver and/or observations) available to the model in real time (<24 hours from collection) without any manual effort when the system is working as intended? (y/n)
column74: Repository in which forecasts are archived
column75: Paper specifies that driver data are publicly available to reproduce the forecasts (according to the paper)
column78: Partnership w/ stakeholder in forecast development mentioned in paper (y/n)
column79: Forecast being used by stakeholder according to paper (y/n)

column3: Phosphorus and chlorophyll in the Bay of Quinte: A time-series/intervention analysis of 1972-2008 data
column4: Nicholls, KH
column8: forecasting is not the primary focus of the paper, but there is one section where they do forecast P concentrations ~ 8 yrs into the future   RPM: OK - lets evaluuate this. they are looking for regime shifts (step-trends) in the bay and use a AR model to show how predictions of TP (not using forceasted data) maintain stationarity and misrepresent the post P-control time period TP concentraions. Again, they do this using already existing data and nothing forecasted or the AR term alone. So - like many things, I would argue this is not a forecast. I mean, I could do the same thing and use my 2017 ebullition TS model and then in 2018 heat up the sediments, increasing overall ebullition, and show that the AR model from 2017 does not predict ebullition well in 2018 because of this forced step-trend I initialted. So - this to me is a TS approach to show how their management intervention worked. Not a forecast, IMO. Happy to argue. Sorry - I think I am becoming a snobby eco-forecaster and I kind of hate that.

column10: I really don't like these types of papers in the context of forecasting. The model is the human experts that were asked to provide estimates of the probability of species establishment with ranges as their uncertainty. I'll include it for now, but am also more than happy to see this paper not on the list if we can justify it.
